Introduction

Point of Care Testing (POCT) can be defined as any analytical test performed on a patient by a healthcare professional outside of the conventional Pathology setting. As a result this is a test that can be used for diagnosis, monitoring or prognosis and may be acted upon resulting in medical intervention on a patient.

POCT when used properly and appropriately can have huge patient advantages as it provides a result quickly and hence allowing for a rapid decision to be made. However, if used inappropriately and by untrained staff incorrect results can be produced and acted upon that may lead to patient harm.

This document is to provide a working directive for all areas that utilise POCT in their clinical management of a patient thereby reducing the risk to patients and staff. This document sits in line with directives as outlined by the Medicines & Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
Scope
The policy applies to all directorates and departments who use POCT devices.

The purpose of this document is to provide standardised management of Point of Care Testing (POCT) devices and procedures throughout the Trust, as recommended by the MHRA thereby ensuring a cost efficient and clinically effective analytical service. This applies to all POCT devices used as a basis for medical intervention whether purchased, loaned or gifted.

This document applies to any member of staff within Mid Essex Hospitals (or managed areas of the Trust), who use a POCT device, are responsible for an analyser, act upon or record results produced by POCT devices, which includes all medical, nursing, laboratory, information technology staff and other members of healthcare teams.
A POCT device includes the following:
Blood gas analyser;
Glucose/Ketone meter;
Urine dipstick;
Haemoglobin meters;
Coagulometer;
Drugs of abuse testing;
Cardiac markers;
Urine HCG meters.
The above list is not an exhaustive list, and other devices may be included.
Definitions

table_items.text: Point of care testing device is any device that provides a diagnostic, prognostic or therapy maintenance result.
A regulatory body that advise the safe and correct use of POCT.
The accreditation body which assesses all Pathology departments to ensure adherence to the international standard ISO 15189:20122. They also outline POCT terms (ISO 22870:2006)3.

A method to test if a POCT device is operationally sound. These are ideally done on a daily basis or at least prior to the use of a device. The frequency of testing is determined by the Pathology department.

Sent out by the Pathology Department usually on a monthly basis and it determines the safe operation of a POCT device from operator to result. It also compares the result to other users across the UK.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
POCT Group duties are:

Advising the hospital on the selection, procurement, maintenance, quality control (QC), external quality assurance (EQA). This group will be represented on and report to the Medical Devices Group (MDAG);
To ensure that the POCT policy is adhered to;
Responsible for the periodic review of the POCT policy and the terms of reference of the POCT committee;
To ensure that the POCT policy is adhered to and followed when devices are being requisitioned and to ensure that the POCT adds to the patient pathway by ensuring clinical effectiveness;
If approved the POCT committee will assist with the requesting clinical lead on the business case;
Will ensure the validation/verification, and implementation are appropriately completed;
Respond to areas that do not adhere to safe practise such as failing to complete QC and regular EQA participation.

Chief Executive – The Chief Executive has overall responsibility to ensure the safe operation of all POCT within the Trust. These duties are delegated to Clinical and Service Directors in their respective health divisions.

4.2.1 Clinical and Service Directors – Clinical and Service Directors are responsible for ensuring that all staff are trained and competent to use the POCT devices within their division. To ensure that the training records are shared with Pathology who must hold a central bank of all those trained. They must also ensure that there is appropriate focus within their division and as advised by the MHRA to have a nominated individual within each Directorate who may liaise for all aspects of POCT.
4.2.2 Biomedical Engineering Department (BME):
To ensure processes are in place so that all devices are under appropriate service contracts and are maintained to manufacturer's guidelines;
To keep a record of all service interventions, planned and corrective maintenance;
To keep a record of all devices within the Trust and to regularly update to ensure that all devices are appropriately monitored by Pathology.
4.2.3 Pathology Department:

In conjunction with BME they are responsible for setting overall strategy and policy to support the effective identification and management of risks that are associated with the acquisition, use, maintenance and repair of POCT devices;
Advise and assist on the appropriate procurement of POCT devices to ensure that they are clinically valid and safe and have uniformity across the Trust;
Assist with interpretation of results;
Troubleshooting where possible;
EQA coordination and interpretation;
Assistance with writing of standard operating procedure (SOP);
Comparability to the laboratory method if available.
4.2.4 POCT Coordinator:
To be the contact point for the Trust for all analytical aspects of POCT;
To direct queries as appropriate;
To monitor all appropriate systems to ensure that POCT analysers are running efficiently;
To distribute EQA;
To interpret EQA reports and to send useful feedback to the POCT users
Where appropriate to write SOP's for users and to offer advice to others regarding content;
To assist with any suggested and appropriate laboratory comparisons;
To highlight any clinical errors/queries to the POCT clinical lead.
4.2.6 Link Persons:
To be the contact point for POCT in their clinical area;
Act as a cascade trainer;
Ensure QC and EQA are performed;
Ensure safe use of any POCT device under the guidance of their Clinical and Service leads;
Ensure ongoing competency of staff.
4.2.6  All staff using/operating POCT:
Ensure that they are trained to use the equipment;
Ensure they use the equipment for its intended purpose;
Ensure they comply with this policy;
To report any incidences involving POCT through Datix.

data.text: Point of Care Testing (POCT)
Rationale
This is a test that sits outside of Pathology and its use can be beneficial in the following:
Where clinical management in an acute setting is enhanced by the result of a diagnostic test;
Where the result in a clinic setting will ensure more effective counselling of the patient and/or change in therapeutic management;
Where the result ensures safe practise of further intervention.
Standard Operating Procedures (SOP)
All POCT devices must have an SOP, which is subject to regular review and is available to, and followed by, all operators of the device. The SOP must be written to standards required by UKAS.
Risk Management
All devices must have a full risk and COSHH assessment.
Health and Safety
All service leads must ensure that these are developed and follow local policies, including the Trust infection control policy.
Infection Control
Before the purchase of any device the decontamination procedure must be established with the manufacturer then incorporated into the UKAS approved SOP.
Patient Results and Connectivity

Where possible all POCT should have IT connectivity to laboratory data systems. If this is not possible then the device should have localised software that can be monitored by Pathology, thereby acting as a reservoir of patient results should they need to be recalled.

5.6.1  If connectivity is not possible then the results must be manually recorded in a Trust approved logbook that details the following information; operator; date; patient; patient hospital number; lot number of test and result. All completed logbooks should be returned to BME.
Quality Control (QC) and External Quality Assurance (EQA)
QC and EQA together ensure the safe working practise of a device and together can often detect an analytical fault that may result in wrong results being reported.
5.7.1 QC frequency will be determined by the test and the device used, and will be set out by Pathology.

5.7.2 Any site that has a device must participate in regular EQA and where possible QC. If this is not adhered to it may result in the removal of devices until it is deemed safe to return them. This is not relevant to devices that patients use at home.
Procurement of Point of Care Testing Equipment

There are two steps to the procurement of a POCT device. The first step is to obtain the approval from the POCT group. This preliminary step in the procurement is to ensure the following criteria has been considered/met:
Is there a clinical need?
How does it benefit the patient?
Has it been discussed with the laboratory?
Can Pathology offer a solution to meet the need?
Is it cost effective?
Does it have end to end connectivity?
How does it compare with the laboratory methodology?
What devices are available in the Trust?

5.8.1 The second step is the submission of an Authority to Invest (ATI) to the Investment Group and Quality Action Group (QAG). These 2 processes are shown below in a flow diagram to demonstrate the steps involved.
5.8.2 As per Medical Devices policy, the POCT group are committed to the standardisation of equipment across the Trust. The reasons for this are as follows:
Reduce risk to patients by ensuring equipment commonality;
Reduce the range of consumables purchased;
Reduce maintenance;
Reduce training requirements;
Reduce purchasing cost by use of competition and purchasing power;
Reduce lifetime costs;
Improve patient care.
Equipment Trial/Evaluation
Any equipment that is to be trialled must be done with the oversight of Pathology
5.9.1 Evaluations will usually be undertaken by Pathology which will allow where possible direct comparison with laboratory methodologies.
5.9.2 Informal visits of representatives and leaving equipment without prior consent from pathology is not permitted.
Role of the POCT Group

To obtain approval from the POCT group A Point of Care Testing Request Form (Appendix 1 of this policy) should be submitted to the group. As much detail and evidence as possible should be submitted to ensure that full consideration is given. The group will review the application in light of the tests available in pathology and what devices are available in the Trust. The Group should have representation from all major directorates to ensure that the application has full consideration. If the proposal accepted Pathology will offer their assistance with the ATI that needs to be submitted to the Investment Group.
ATI and the Investment Group

The approval of the application at the POCT group does not mean that the device can be purchased. An ATI will need to be filled in, and Pathology will assist the requestor with this where possible. The ATI is then submitted for full approval at the Investment Group and QAG.
Role of Procurement

The involvement of Procurement will depend on the device being requested and how the device will be procured but commercial and business support will be provided to ensure the needs of the Trust are met. This may involve application to a framework, or a tender process.
Training Requirements
Only staff that have been trained and deemed competent should operate POCT devices.

Following procurement, and installation, relevant staff must be trained, including a nominated link person. The training plan should initially be implemented by the manufacturer with an ideal training level of 75% of relevant staff prior to a device “go-live”.
Regular training should be provided after the installation. Where possible the training should be a mixture of both manufacturer and link persons.
For many devices update training is required to ensure safe practise.
A record must be maintained by each individual area and all training records must be sent to Pathology. This record must be kept up to date.
Where possible barcodes/passwords will be issued. No operator will share these with another member of staff. This will be in line with the Trust's IT policy.
Monitoring and Audit
Audits will be conducted by both Trust staff and where possible by POCT manufacturers to ensure compliance with MHRA guidance and this policy.
The findings of the audits must be fed back to the POCT Coordinator and the actions will then be decided and discussed with the relevant clinical areas.
Any incident that occurs as a result of equipment failure, failure of correct training, or other invention must be reported through DATIX.
All relevant POCT Datix incidences should be highlighted to the POCT Clinical Lead, POCT Coordinator and the Pathology Quality Manager.
POCT incidence trends will be reviewed at the POCT Group.
POCT audits will also be reviewed at the POCT Group
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be circulated clinically and professional approval confirmed by the Asset Owner prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform appropriate staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranet.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of the individual.
